Oil Leakage on Hydraulic Press

20/7/2025 – Machine HP-200, Assembly Line 3, Factory Z, Horsens, Denmark – 13:05
Author: Bob Jørgensen
#oil-leak #hydraulic-system #pressure-drop #maintenance-history #root-cause-analysis #daily-check #cleaning-schedule #temperature-log #machine-up-time #safety-check #replacement-needed
During the routine inspection of the HP-200 unit, a significant drop in hydraulic pressure was observed. The pressure reading fell 30% below the safe operational threshold, prompting an immediate investigation. Upon approach, oil was visibly leaking from the rear actuator assembly.
Visual inspection confirmed that the fluid was hydraulic oil, likely ISO VG 46 based on consistency and color. The source of the leak was quickly identified—a cracked metal fitting on the secondary hose line, likely due to prolonged wear or pressure fatigue. This component had previously been noted as borderline during a March inspection but had not yet been replaced.

After isolating the issue, the hydraulic system was shut down, and a temporary sealant was applied to limit further leakage. A replacement fitting was requested from inventory, with estimated arrival by 15:00. A maintenance log entry was created, and the incident was flagged for review during the monthly safety audit.
Historical logs indicate two similar failures on this machine in the past 6 months, suggesting a recurring weakness in the current hose design or fitting specification. It may be necessary to evaluate a reinforced or upgraded component as part of a broader reliability improvement effort.
Ambient temperature and vibration logs were reviewed to rule out environmental causes. No anomalies were detected in either metric leading up to the failure.


Technician note (voice transcribed): “Recommend replacing not only the cracked fitting but inspecting all other joints under the same pressure load. We may be facing a batch-related durability issue.”
The task has been marked as 'In Progress', and the maintenance supervisor has been notified. Estimated downtime for this unit is two hours. Updated inspection protocols will include monthly hose integrity scans and stress-point monitoring.

Hydraulic Oil Leakage – Incident Resolution Process

20/7/2025 – Machine HP-200, Assembly Line 3, Factory Z, Horsens, Denmark – 13:05
Documented by: Bob Jørgensen
#hydraulic-system #oil-leak #maintenance-process #component-failure #inspection-protocol #root-cause #corrective-action #downtime #replacement-procedure
1. Problem Identification
A pressure drop of approximately 30% was detected in the hydraulic circuit of the HP-200 press. A physical inspection revealed visible oil leakage originating from the rear actuator housing.
2. Containment Measures
The machine was placed in safe shutdown mode to prevent further fluid loss. A temporary industrial-grade sealant was applied to limit leakage until permanent repair could be executed.
3. Root Cause Analysis
The leak was traced to a cracked metal fitting on the secondary hydraulic hose. The component showed signs of material fatigue. Two prior failures of similar fittings on this machine were documented earlier in 2025, suggesting a systemic issue with the current component batch or design.
4. Corrective Action
A replacement fitting was ordered from inventory (ETA: 15:00 same day). Technician prepared hose for replacement. All adjacent fittings were visually inspected for early signs of wear or stress.
5. Verification
Environmental logs (temperature and vibration) for the previous 48 hours showed no anomalies. This rules out external contributing factors. Pressure logs were validated post-repair to ensure operational stability.
6. Documentation & Follow-Up
Maintenance records have been updated. A follow-up inspection is scheduled for 21/7/2025 to verify the integrity of the replaced component. Inspection protocol was revised to include monthly checks of all secondary hose fittings.
